Dialogue:
CX: Hello. How is the COVID-19 situation over there?
BU: Hello. Are you asking about the infection situation in our area?
CX: Yes, current infection numbers in your area.
BU: I don't watch the news about corona anymore. Nothing changes.
CX: I see. Less stress that way.
BU: Yes, it's always reported, and I don't mind it anymore.
CX: Constant worry can be harmful.
BU: Exactly. I just avoid troubling others if I'm infected.
CX: Right. Taking precautions is important.
BU: Let’s change the subject.
CX: Sure. Any positive news you're interested in?
BU: The Chunichi Dragons won yesterday.
CX: Do you like baseball? I'm a Giants fan.
BU: I support the Chunichi Dragons.
CX: Ohno was impressive yesterday.
BU: It's a shame about the Giants.
CX: The pitching staff struggles.
BU: Hirauchi should improve. I'm cheering for Walker and Nakayama from the Giants.
CX: Yes, if they perform well and Okamoto gets better.
BU: Okamoto was removed from the fourth position. Nakata is doing well.
CX: Okamoto is struggling. Nakata's home run was nice.
BU: Nakata has improved since the Chunichi game.
CX: Hitting a home run off Rydel is impressive.
BU: First home run of the year. Poor battery performance though.
CX: The catcher's lead is a concern.
BU: Commentators criticize Kinotaku's leadership this year.
CX: A strong catcher is crucial.
BU: Even if they can’t hit or lead well, a winning catcher is needed.
CX: Someone like Yakult's Nakamura.
BU: Nakamura is good, though his performance dipped after his jersey number changed.

CX: Thank you in advance. Are there any long holidays like the Obon holiday?  
BU: No long holidays like Obon. Anything else you need?  
CX: I see. I don't have anything in particular either.  
BU: Are you off today?  
CX: Yes, I'm currently on a break. I lost my job due to COVID-19, so I have free time now.  
BU: Are you looking for a new job?  
CX: Yes, but I have some time to decide, so I'm taking it slow and doing some studying as well.  
BU: Do you have any specific job preferences?  
CX: Thank you. I am considering my options thoroughly before making any decisions.  
BU: What was your previous job?  
CX: I was a TV assistant director.  
BU: In Tokyo?  
CX: Yes, I worked in Tokyo.  
BU: Did you work for a well-known TV company?  
CX: I worked for a production company, so the name might not be recognizable.  
BU: Who is the most famous person you met?  
CX: I worked with Banana Man, who are quite famous now.  
BU: I enjoy comedians.  
CX: Yes, Banana Man are very kind and funny.  
BU: They appear on many TV shows.  
CX: Yes. Mr. Himura is quite quiet during breaks though.  
BU: Many talents are like that.  
CX: Mr. Shitara, on the other hand, makes small jokes even during breaks.  
BU: It must be a fun environment to work in.  
CX: Yes, it's very lively and bustling.  
BU: A good atmosphere likely contributes to a good program.  
CX: Absolutely. It was difficult when working on shows where the staff didn’t get along.  
BU: Viewers notice such dynamics.  
CX: I try my best to prevent that from happening.  
BU: Enjoying your work is important. Thank you for sharing!

CX: Hello. Do you have any plans for today or tomorrow?  
BU: Hello. No specific plans. Do you have any?  
CX: Not really. I feel like just relaxing.  
BU: Understood. Have you eaten rice?  
CX: I'm planning to have lunch soon.  
BU: Have you decided what to eat?  
CX: I'm thinking of having pork shabu-shabu.  
BU: That sounds nice!  
CX: It's quite simple, just boiled pork and bean sprouts.  
BU: Do you make the broth from scratch?  
CX: No, I just use hot water.  
BU: I see. When I hear "shabu-shabu," I think of a restaurant dish.  
CX: I think of it as boiling water and adding meat and vegetables.  
BU: That sounds delicious too. Do you use ponzu sauce?  
CX: I use a grated daikon radish sauce.  
BU: Is it mixed with ponzu sauce?  
CX: It doesn't have much of a ponzu flavor.  
BU: It's refreshing and delicious. Do you like grated daikon radish?  
CX: I like it, but I prefer buying it pre-grated.  
BU: It's easier that way. Grilled fish with grated daikon and soy sauce is exceptional.  
CX: It pairs well with fatty fish like Atka mackerel.  
BU: Agreed. Grilled fish with grated daikon and soy sauce is delicious.  
CX: I only have it occasionally at set meal restaurants.  
BU: The fish at those places is good. I'm getting hungry.  
CX: What will you have for lunch?  
BU: I don't usually eat lunch.  
CX: I see. Have a great day.  
BU: Thank you. Goodbye!

CX: Hello. Is it hot over there?  
CO: Yes, it's hot.  
CX: Are you okay with heatstroke?  
CO: I'm being careful.  
CX: Stay hydrated and take care.  
CO: Thanks. My friend had heatstroke.  
CX: Was your friend safe?  
CO: Yes, but it was dangerous.  
CX: Emergency transport is difficult due to COVID.  
CO: They hadn't been drinking enough water and collapsed.  
CX: Hydration is important.  
CO: The doctor reminded me.  
CX: There's news about a typhoon coming. Are you okay?  
CO: We're safe. How about there?  
CX: It's okay here too.  
CO: Are you prepared for disasters?  
CX: Not really, but we have some water and canned food.  
CO: I am prepared for typhoons.  
CX: Good.  
CO: Without preparation, there's a risk of damage.  
CX: My home is on the second floor of an apartment.  
CO: Last year, there was damage from flying signs during the typhoon.  
CX: That's serious.  
CO: I've been careful since then.  
CX: With all the climate news, it's concerning.  
CO: The typhoon is affecting the Kanto region now.  
CX: It seems so. Sports and events are being canceled.  
CO: I'm concerned about my friend in the Kanto region.  
CX: I hope everything is okay.  
CO: Yes, I hope so too.

CX: Thank you in advance. Do you have something like an Obon holiday?  
CO: Yes, I have about a week off for the Obon holiday.  
CX: That's nice. Do you have any plans for the holiday?  
CO: No specific plans this year.  
CX: I see. Is it difficult to make plans because of COVID-19?  
CO: Yes, that's the reason. If it wasn't for COVID-19, I would have traveled.  
CX: Really, how long will the coronavirus continue?  
CO: Since it’s ongoing, I will stay home this time.  
CX: I hope things settle down quickly so we can go out and have fun.  
CO: Yes, do you have any plans?  
CX: I don't have an Obon holiday itself.  
CO: Are you working?  
CX: No. I’m taking a break from work now, so I’ve been off all the time.  
CO: Understood.  
CX: That’s right. Also, since this summer is hot, it might be difficult to go outside.  
CO: Don’t overexert yourself.  
CX: With the coronavirus situation, I’m wondering if I won’t be able to do anything this summer.  
CO: How long have you been resting?  
CX: It has already been about two and a half years.  
CO: That’s a long time. What was your previous job?  
CX: I was working part-time at a gas station, among other jobs.  
CO: Juggling multiple jobs sounds busy.  
CX: The work itself is easy, but working day and night was really tough.  
CO: Are you not looking for a job yet?  
CX: Yes. I am carefully considering what to do next.  
CO: It’s difficult to move around now with the coronavirus situation.  
CX: That’s really it. There are fewer job openings as well.  
CO: Jobs have decreased and many people are looking for work.  
CX: I wonder what will happen next.  
CO: I understand.

CX: Hello! Nice to meet you!
AT: Nice to meet you. How can I assist you today?
CX: Is it hot there today?
AT: It's humid, likely due to an approaching typhoon.
CX: I see, it's quite hot and stuffy here too.
AT: It has been hot lately since it's summer.
CX: It feels like it has been getting hotter and hotter these past few years.
AT: Yes, some regions have exceeded 40 degrees this year.
CX: That's right. Actually, I went to Tokyo during that period, and it was extremely hot.
AT: That must have been uncomfortable. Indoor places are usually cool.
CX: To prevent heatstroke, we basically played inside the indoor building all the time.
AT: That's a good strategy. Intense heat and water damage affect other regions too.
CX: Certainly. In the area where I live, it has been raining heavily this past week.
AT: Any damage to your house?
CX: Fortunately, there was no damage to the house.
AT: My parent's hometown is Gojome Town in Akita Prefecture, and it's being reported in the news today.
CX: I see. Are you safe at the moment?
AT: Yes, I am safe. The weather has been unstable.
CX: That's true. The coronavirus is annoying enough as it is.
AT: It's becoming more prevalent, with frequent reports about medical strain.
CX: They said on the news that emergency transport can't keep up due to COVID-19 and heatstroke, and it's scary.
AT: Yes, it is worrying that some people cannot receive treatment for non-COVID illnesses.
CX: It's painful that there are people who cannot receive medical care and pass away due to non-COVID reasons.
AT: COVID-19 has generated various types, and it seems uncertain when it will end.
CX: Last year I thought it was over after getting the vaccine, but it seems like it will continue for a while.
AT: Yes, the fourth dose is becoming common now.
CX: This is the fourth time this month, but I'm sure there will be a fifth and sixth time as well.
AT: This is already the fourth time. Have you experienced side effects in the past?
CX: The side effects of the third Moderna shot were tough, so I really don't want to get another one.
AT: That is understandable. Please take care of your health.

CX: Good evening. Is it almost time for dinner?  
AT: Yes, it's time to start getting ready.  
CX: What are you planning to eat?  
AT: I haven't decided yet. What will you eat?  
CX: Miso soup and canned fish.  
AT: Is that all?  
CX: Yes, I’m not feeling well, so I’m keeping dinner light.  
AT: Fish is nutritious.  
CX: I’m just aiming for the essentials.  
AT: Do you eat vegetables?  
CX: Yes, in the miso soup.  
AT: Understood. Do you eat properly in the morning and afternoon?  
CX: Yes, substantial breakfast and lunch, light dinner.  
AT: Noted.  
CX: But I’ve been gaining weight recently.  
AT: Could it be lack of exercise?  
CX: That, and maybe my autonomic nerves.  
AT: Addressing that is important.  
CX: I wake up frequently at night.  
AT: That can affect sleep quality.  
CX: Cooler or stable temperature would help.  
AT: Do you have an air conditioner?  
CX: No, I live in Hokkaido.  
AT: Summers can be hot there.  
CX: It’s been especially hot recently.  
AT: Consider installing an air conditioner.  
CX: I’ll think about it next year.  
AT: Research measures for heatstroke and better sleep.  
CX: Yes, I’d like to install it in early spring.  
AT: Good plan.

CX: Do you have any plans for tomorrow?  
AT: No plans for tomorrow. How about you?  
CX: No plans either.  
AT: I often relax on Sunday.  
CX: What kind of work do you do?  
AT: System engineer, mainly desk work.  
CX: Tough on shoulders and eyes?  
AT: Shoulders and lower back get stiff.  
CX: Desk work is hard on the body.  
AT: It feels uncomfortable.  
CX: I still massage myself sometimes.  
AT: I use massage machines and go to a chiropractor.  
CX: I used to use something with adzuki beans for warming.  
AT: What is it?  
CX: Heat it in the microwave and place it on your eyes or shoulders.  
AT: Improves blood circulation.  
CX: Plus, it can be used multiple times.  
AT: Body gets stiff when reading books?  
CX: Yes, I stretch to ease stiffness.  
AT: Stretching is hard to do at the office.  
CX: How about turning your neck or pulling your arms back?  
AT: That should be fine. I'll move around when working from home.  
CX: Are you able to work from home?  
AT: Half going to the office, half remote work.  
CX: One good thing about COVID-19 is working from home.  
AT: Cuts down on commute time.  
CX: Crowded trains are tough.  
AT: I'll make better use of working from home.  
CX: I hope telecommuting becomes more widespread.  
AT: Sure, thank you.
